The loosely structured Ethics

The Academic Integrity

University," the Code reads. The

In a major change from earlier

Hufnail, Director of the

and increased direct costs are all
costs unforeseen, and usually not
provided for at the time of a grant application.

Academic Reports stay as written
By JAN HAN1MERMAN
Student Council President
Mike Lenardo said yesterday that
he does not foresee the SC
updating the Academic Reports
which it presented to the
Academic Council last year.
"I think that it would be much
more effective if we select a
major and non-major for each
department to sit down with the
appropriate faculty members and
discuss problems with teaching,"
he stated.
However, Lenardo does not
believe that the completion of
the Reports signals an end to
student evaluation of teaching.
"Implementing the original ten
suggestions is not our only goal,"
he contended, "Rather I see a
continuing dialogue on
undergraduate academic needs."
The first official use of the

Reports will be made this fall
when the Academic Council
refers to them in its yearly
evaluation of departments. Dean
of Arts and Sciences George
Owen said that "though some
faculty members are not in
agreement with its conclusions,
any input we receive is helpful."
Owen will also introduce the
major recommendations of the
reports over the course of several
Academic Council meetings.
1Dichotomy
"I didn't want to place all the
suggestions on the first agenda
for fear the entire program might
be killed," he explained. "We
plan to address these questions in
the same straightforward manner
in which they were presented.'"
Lenardo does see a problem in
how the various measures
recommended by the SC can be

effectively implemented.
"Clearly there is a dichotomy
between the matters that can be
handled by the department and
those by the Academic Council."
"There must be enthusiasm on
the part of both groups and
pressure by the Dean to rectify
anomalous teaching situations,"
he offered.
The SC head also expressed his
pleasure that one
suggestion—that faculty members
keep regular office hours and
adhere to the schedule—had been
acted on. He added that the next
priority should be improvement
of the "grossly inadequate
graduate student teaching
situation."
"Uniform tests and grading
policy must be implemented to
upgrade the quality of TA
instruction."

Hopkins Hospital initiating cost-cutting program
By DONALD MORISATO
In the face of soaring costs,
the Hopkins Hospital is initiating
a Cost Improvement Program
designed to help the Hospital
cope with its mounting financial
burdens.
B.J. Norris, the Hospital's
Director of Public Affairs, said
yesterday that operating
expenses for 1975-76 will be an
estimated 15 percent higher than
costs incurred during the last
fiscal year, a result of increases in
salaries, benefits, facilities

development, equipment, and
maintenance, food, and fuel
costs. Fuel bills alone will
account for a one million dollar
increase in expenditures this
year.
To partially offset this rise in
expenditures, the Hospital
announced a seven percent
increase last June. However, this
decision was contested by the
Health Services Review
Commission, a regulatory and
review agency of the state of
Maryland. In July, an

out-of-court settlement resulted
in a three and a half percent
increase. An application for an
additional hike of the same size is
currently pending.
The Cost Improvement
Program, as explained by Dr.
Robert Heyssel, Executive Vice
President and firector of the
Hospital, is "a way to identify
methods of reducing
expenditures such as energy,
labor, paper supply and food
supply costs; to do things more
efficiently and at less cost; and to

avoid new costs while
maintaining, and hopefully
improving the quality of services.
"We have a responsibility to
our patients, who, after all,
ultimately pay for services, to
assure that we achieve our
objectives in patient care at the
lowest possible price," he said.
Pooks for the last fiscal year,
which have just been .closed.
reveal an approximate $700,000
operating loss. This compares
favorably to 1973-74, at which
time operating revenues increased

to $64.8 million, but did not
keep pace with costs, which
reached $66.3 million, leaving
the Hospital with an operating
loss of $1.4 million. [bring that
year, the Hospital rendered $5.2
million in unreimbursed services.
Endowment income and gifts
designated for operation of $1.2'
million did not fully cover the
operating loss, leaving the net
loss of nearly $200,000.

In the middle of last night's episode of "The World at
War," providence saw fit to interrupt with the news that yet
another attempt had been made on President Ford's life.
Though the world is no longer "at War" violence is more
prevelant in our day-to-day lives than it was 30 years ago.
The freedom and security that Americans sought to preserve
in World War II becomes increasingly meaningless as people in
this country hide—with good reason—from the crime that is
rampant on our streets.
The two attempted slayings of the President provide stark
evidence—if any were needed—that proponents of effective
gun control legislation have not suffered from any shortage
of arguments for their viewpoint. The infamous assassinations
of the past 15 years have included one President, one
Senator, and the most influential- civil rights leader in the
country's history.
Legislation for gun control—the obvious starting point to a
solution to the violence in our society—has been stymied
primarily by National Rifle Association lobbyists and others.
who misinterpret the Constitution's guarantee of the Right to
bear arms.
It seems incredible that President Ford, after one graphic
demonstration of the need for control of firearms failed to
modify his position of limited regulation. Ford, along with

simple fact that if guns were taken off the street, no one
could be shot.

citizen's ability to fight off a military takeover? It would take

will undoubtedly become less frequent.
What we do lose is the fear that each sane person shares
because he knows that guns are readily available to any one.
It would serve Congress and Mr. Ford well to consider that
before another attempt is made on his life.

Boris and Sonja and Love and Death
By MIKE DEAK
There seems to be no doubt
that Woody Allen is the best
American filmmaker working
today. Which (not to take
anything away from Allen)
doesn't say much, considering
his main competition consists of
a babbling Mel Brooks whose
films have all the stoic appeal of
a well-placed whoopee cushion, a
confused Mike Nichols whose
later_ films only guise as
comedies because . they can't
pass for anything else, and an
old, tired Billy Wilder whose
workd have lost all their front
page excitement. But this is not
to say that Allen has won his
titled simply by default. With
"Love and Death," Allen has
finally 'reached cinematic and
artistic maturity. The
inexperience and Uncertainty
(cheap jokes, dubious
camerawork and editing, an
almost childlish manical tone)
that marred his earlier films have
now completely and gloriously
disappeared.
"Love and Death" is a
brilliantly funny and cruel
parody of Russian literature and
film. Allusions to Tolstoy,

Dostoevsky, and Eisenstein fly
by like one-liners delivered by an
intellectual, esoteric Henny
Youngman concerned for once
with content and subtlety rather
than just spurious laughs. Like all
classical Russian literature of
despair and doubt, the film seems
to imply the non-existence of
God. Few have had the guts to
tackle the making of a comedy
about this, and even fewer have
had the talent to succeed.
Somehow Allen pulls it off. For
example, consider a recent quote
by Allen, "If there is a God, I
reason, why are there such things
as famine and daytime
television?"
At tie beginning of"Love and
Death," we learn that Boris
(Woody Allen) has had the usual
Russian childhood. He
remembers dreams of tuxedoed
waiters emerging from dozens of
upright coffins and dancing
together. When he was about ten,
Boris encountered Death, an
apparently old man (we never do
see Death's face) carrying a sickle
like Father Time and dressed in a
pure white shroud. About the
time of Napoleon's first invasion
of Russia—the • same period as

War and Peace,—Boris has
reached manhood and fallen in
love with a cousin, Sonja
(beautifully played by Diane,
Keaton). Instead of falling- into
bed together, they fall deep into
senseless, viciously circular
epistemological talk, nihilistic
Russian philosophy, reduced to
the gibberish it should be. Sonja
refused to rnary Boris and gives
herself instead to a ridiculously
boring merchant and Boris goes
off to fight the French. Of
course, he marches off
reluctantly, telling his assembled
family, "My doctor says war
might be dangerous for my
health." In basic training, Boris is
accosted by a black drill sergeant
with a Georgian accent. Battle
bewilders Boris, so he hides in a
cannon that suddenly runs
amuck and accidentally fires him
into a tent of French generals,
killing all of them. He returns a
hero.
Meanwhile, Sonja has been
playing musical beds in St.
Petersburg and her husband has
died in a duel defending her
honor. Which leaves the door
open to Boris, but at the opera
he catches the eye of a 'countess

whose boyfriend than challenges
Boris to a duel. Thinking he will
surely lose, Sonja agrees to marry
Boris. However, Boris survives
the duel, they get married, and
then plot to assisinate Napoleon
the next time he invades Russia.
Which leads us to the end where
God plays one last practical joke
on Boris.
In one of their murky
discussions, Sonja suddenly says,
"Love is everything," and the
way she says it, we're almost
convinced it's the only 'universal
truth. For Woody Allen, love is
indeed everything. All his heroes,
from the secret agent in "Casino
Royale" to the defrosted
anachronism in "Sleeper" are
unwitting victims of a hostile
world. They are continually
searching for love, and because
it's a comedy of course, they
eventually find love, filling a
need not only for themselves for
us as well. Woody Allen, among
all contemporary filmmakers, has
been the only one to seriously
and humbly inherit the only
truly American genre besides the
western, for this theme of love is
the basis of all classic American
comedy.

undergraduate academic needs."

evaluation of departments. Dean

In the middle of last night's episode of "The World at
War," providence saw fit to interrupt with the news that yet
another attempt had been made on President Ford's life.
Though the world is no longer "at War" violence is more
prevelant in our day-to-day lives than it was 30 years ago.
The freedom and security that Americans sought to preserve
in World War II becomes increasingly meaningless as people in
this country hide—with good reason—from the crime that is
rampant on our streets.

evidence—if any were needed—that proponents of effective
gun control legislation have not suffered from any shortage
of arguments for their viewpoint. The infamous assassinations
of the past 15 years have included one President, one
Senator, and the most influential- civil rights leader in the
country's history.
Legislation for gun control—the obvious starting point to a
solution to the violence in our society—has been stymied
primarily by National Rifle Association lobbyists and others.

bear arms.

, And in return for this gain, what would we lose? The

Boris and Sonja and Love and Death
By MIKE DEAK
There seems to be no doubt
that Woody Allen is the best
American filmmaker working
today. Which (not to take
anything away from Allen)
doesn't say much, considering
his main competition consists of
a babbling Mel Brooks whose
films have all the stoic appeal of
a well-placed whoopee cushion, a
confused Mike Nichols whose
later_ films only guise as
comedies because . they can't
pass for anything else, and an
old, tired Billy Wilder whose
workd have lost all their front
page excitement. But this is not
to say that Allen has won his
titled simply by default. With
"Love and Death," Allen has
finally 'reached cinematic and
artistic maturity. The
inexperience and Uncertainty
(cheap jokes, dubious
camerawork and editing, an
almost childlish manical tone)
that marred his earlier films have
now completely and gloriously
disappeared.
"Love and Death" is a
brilliantly funny and cruel
parody of Russian literature and
film. Allusions to Tolstoy,

Dostoevsky, and Eisenstein fly
by like one-liners delivered by an
intellectual, esoteric Henny
Youngman concerned for once
with content and subtlety rather
than just spurious laughs. Like all
classical Russian literature of
despair and doubt, the film seems
to imply the non-existence of
God. Few have had the guts to
tackle the making of a comedy
about this, and even fewer have
had the talent to succeed.
Somehow Allen pulls it off. For
example, consider a recent quote
by Allen, "If there is a God, I
reason, why are there such things
as famine and daytime
television?"
At tie beginning of"Love and
Death," we learn that Boris
(Woody Allen) has had the usual
Russian childhood. He
remembers dreams of tuxedoed
waiters emerging from dozens of
upright coffins and dancing
together. When he was about ten,
Boris encountered Death, an
apparently old man (we never do
see Death's face) carrying a sickle
like Father Time and dressed in a
pure white shroud. About the
time of Napoleon's first invasion
of Russia—the • same period as

War and Peace,—Boris has
reached manhood and fallen in
love with a cousin, Sonja
(beautifully played by Diane,
Keaton). Instead of falling- into
bed together, they fall deep into
senseless, viciously circular
epistemological talk, nihilistic
Russian philosophy, reduced to
the gibberish it should be. Sonja
refused to rnary Boris and gives
herself instead to a ridiculously
boring merchant and Boris goes
off to fight the French. Of
course, he marches off
reluctantly, telling his assembled
family, "My doctor says war
might be dangerous for my
health." In basic training, Boris is
accosted by a black drill sergeant
with a Georgian accent. Battle
bewilders Boris, so he hides in a
cannon that suddenly runs
amuck and accidentally fires him
into a tent of French generals,
killing all of them. He returns a
hero.
Meanwhile, Sonja has been
playing musical beds in St.
Petersburg and her husband has
died in a duel defending her
honor. Which leaves the door
open to Boris, but at the opera
he catches the eye of a 'countess

whose boyfriend than challenges
Boris to a duel. Thinking he will
surely lose, Sonja agrees to marry
Boris. However, Boris survives
the duel, they get married, and
then plot to assisinate Napoleon
the next time he invades Russia.
Which leads us to the end where
God plays one last practical joke
on Boris.
In one of their murky
discussions, Sonja suddenly says,
"Love is everything," and the
way she says it, we're almost
convinced it's the only 'universal
truth. For Woody Allen, love is
indeed everything. All his heroes,
from the secret agent in "Casino
Royale" to the defrosted
anachronism in "Sleeper" are
unwitting victims of a hostile
world. They are continually
searching for love, and because
it's a comedy of course, they
eventually find love, filling a
need not only for themselves for
us as well. Woody Allen, among
all contemporary filmmakers, has
been the only one to seriously
and humbly inherit the only
truly American genre besides the
western, for this theme of love is
the basis of all classic American
comedy.
